title: Raising the Fuel Tank (for access only)

body.body: Raising the Fuel Tank (for access only)
Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Never drain fuel from the fuel tank using non-approved, non-professional standard fuel handling equipment.
A fire causing destruction of property and injury to persons may result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Always use approved, professional fuel handling equipment.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Draining or extraction of fuel from a fuel tank must be carried out in a well ventilated area.

The receptacle used to contain the fuel must be more than adequate for the full amount of fuel to be extracted or drained. The receptacle should be clearly marked with its contents, and placed in a safe storage area which meets the requirements of local authority regulations.
When fuel has been extracted or drained from a fuel tank, the precautions governing naked lights and ignition sources should be maintained.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Using proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain the fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the omega clip from the main harness conduit.
Remove the front fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (right hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Remove the front fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Remove the fixings from the front bracket.
Do not lift the fuel tank further than necessary.
Fuel tank infill panels could become damaged if the fuel tank is lifted too far.
Failure to protect the painted panels may cause damage to the surface(s).
With the aid of an assistant, tilt the fuel tank rearward to gain access to the underside and the front fuse box.

search: Raising the Fuel Tank (for access only)
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Never drain fuel from the fuel tank using non-approved, non-professional standard fuel handling equipment.
A fire causing destruction of property and injury to persons may result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Always use approved, professional fuel handling equipment.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Draining or extraction of fuel from a fuel tank must be carried out in a well ventilated area.

The receptacle used to contain the fuel must be more than adequate for the full amount of fuel to be extracted or drained. The receptacle should be clearly marked with its contents, and placed in a safe storage area which meets the requirements of local authority regulations.
When fuel has been extracted or drained from a fuel tank, the precautions governing naked lights and ignition sources should be maintained.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Perform the following operations:
Seats - Removal
Battery - Removal
Using proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain the fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the omega clip from the main harness conduit.
Remove the front fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (right hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Omega clip
Battery negative lead
Remove the front fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Stop screw (left hand shown)
Rear bracket
Remove the fixings from the front bracket.
Fuel tank
Fixings
Do not lift the fuel tank further than necessary.
Fuel tank infill panels could become damaged if the fuel tank is lifted too far.
Failure to protect the painted panels may cause damage to the surface(s).
With the aid of an assistant, tilt the fuel tank rearward to gain access to the underside and the front fuse box.
Front fuse box location
